description.narrative: Financing of Rapid Assessment of Keeping Girls in School (KGS) which is one of the three components of the Girls' Education and Women's Empowerment and Livelihood (GEWEL) project implemented by the Zambian government and financed by a loan from the World Bank. The objective of the assessment was to improve the effectiveness of Zambia's social protection system by improving the effectiveness of the Keeping Girls in School component of the GEWEL project.

Financing of Rapid Assessment of Keeping Girls in School (KGS) which is one of the two components of the Girls' Education and Women's Empowerment and Livelihood (GEWEL) project implemented by the Zambian government and financed by a loan from the World Bank. The rapid assessment is expected to provide input to the development of the next phase of the GEWEL project which is prepared by the World Bank during 2019. The Embassy will during 2019 also appraise potential support to the implementation of phase 2 of the project.

Insatsen finansierar en studie som ska ge underlag till vidareutveckling av Keeping Girls in School (KGS) vilket är en komponent av Girls' Education and Women's Empowerment and Livelihood (GEWEL) project som genomförs av den zambiska regeringen och finansieras genom ett lån från Världsbanken. Projektets fas två förbereds av Världsbanken under 2019 och studien förväntas bidra med kunskap för att ytterligare öka genomslaget för projektets KGS-komponent. Ambassaden kommer under 2019 att ta ställning till att eventuellt ge stöd också till genomförandet av projektets fas 2.

description.narrative: The Rapid Assessment has resulted in insights into success factors and shortcomings of the Keeping Girls in School and provided recommendations on how to improve the design going forward. Important findings include: - School retention, rather than take-up is the main challenge to achieving project objectives. During its first two years of implementation (2017-2018), KGS issues offer letters to 26 426 girls, out of whom 22 249 (84%) reported to school and had their school fees paid by the project. However, only around 16 000 among them (60%) attended school in a specific term. - Lack of information about KGS benefits and conditions hindered take-up. Only 31% of girls who did not take-up KGS reported receiving an offer letter, compared to 83% of those who took it up. Confusion about whether KGS covers exam fees as well as ad hoc requirements to repeat grades further discouraged out-of-school girls from taking up KGS and returning to school. - Girls are often not able to stay in school even when school fees are covered because of other associated costs. Lack of school supplies was the most common reason why girls said they did not attend school. The design of KGS assumed that Social Cash Transfers (SCT) households, where girls are targeted from, can use their monthly allowance to buy school supplies and attend to other household needs, but SCT have been irregular. - Distance to school and insufficient boarding capacity is another significant barrier to consistent attendance and enrollment. Of those who took-up KGS, 72% are day scholars, 19% are weekly boarders and 9% attend boarding school. Moreover, weekly boarding facilities, if not properly managed and maintained, present a safety risk in terms of SRGBV. - Not all beneficiaries were selected from SCT households. as per the project design. Analysis of administrative data was able to match 83% of KGS beneficiaries with households from the SCT beneficiaries roster using household head and girl information. - If given the choice, most interviewed beneficiaries would have preferred to go to a different school, preferably a boarding school. 56% of respondents said they would rather go to a different school, ideally a boarding school where they could focus better. Many of them explained, however, that their academic performance was not good enough to qualify for boarding school.
